kick in.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to start or to begin to have an effect
kick in.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The storm is expected to kick in shortly after sunrise.
The painkillers kicked in and he became sleepy.
kick in.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to join with others in giving money or help
kick in.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Bill never wants to kick in.
We were each asked to kick in 50 cents toward the cost.
kick in.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to injure someone badly by kicking them
kick in.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: He threatened to come round and kick my head in.
kick in.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to kick a locked door so hard that it breaks open
kick in.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: We had to get the police to kick the door in.
kick in.translation[1].definitions[0].de: if a system, arrangement, event etc kicks in, it begins to have an effect
kick in.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Many lawyers are hurrying to arrange settlements before the new tax rules kick in.
kick in.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to join with others in giving or making money, especially in order to help people
kick in.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: In eight years, companies have kicked in $300,000 towards community improvements.
Sales per employee - one measure of how the staff may or may not be kicking in for a company - rose by 8%.
